---
date: 2026-02-01T12:00:00.000Z
institution: Independent (U.S. Navy Patent Submission)
impact: >-
  Although the U.S. Navy, allegedly, did not deploy the system during WWII, the
  concept resurfaced decades later as electronic components miniaturized.


  By the late 20th century, frequency-hopping became foundational to secure wireless communication standards worldwide.
references: >-2
   
  Electronic Frontier Foundation. (1997). *Hedy Lamarr and frequency hopping*.




  Lamarr, H., & Antheil, G. (1942). *Secret communication system*. U.S. Patent No. 2,292,387.



  Smithsonian National Museum of American History. (n.d.). *Hedy Lamarr papers*.
field_secondary: Engineering
title: Frequency-Hopping Spread Spectrum Communication
inventor: Hedy Lamarr (with George Antheil)
year: 1940–1942
field:
  - Computer Science / Computing
  - Mathematics
description: A frequency-hopping communication system designed to prevent enemy
  interception and jamming of radio-controlled signals. The invention introduced
  a method of rapidly switching transmission frequencies, laying the groundwork
  for modern wireless technologies including Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and GPS.
problem: During World War II, radio-controlled torpedoes were easily jammed by
  enemy forces, making them unreliable in combat. Secure, interference-resistant
  communication was a critical unresolved military challenge.
how_it_works: >-
  The system synchronized a transmitter and receiver to rapidly shift between
  radio frequencies in a predetermined pattern.


  Like a conversation that changes rooms every second, the signal became nearly impossible to intercept or disrupt without knowing the sequence.


  Lamarr adapted concepts from music theory and mechanical synchronization to engineer a communication method that appeared chaotic to outsiders but remained perfectly ordered to its users.
barriers: >-
  
  The invention was allegedly classified, misunderstood, and dismissed in part due to Lamarr’s status as a woman and a Hollywood actress.


  Mechanical implementation challenges and institutional bias delayed its adoption for decades.
why_it_matters: >-
  Frequency-hopping principles underpin modern wireless communication, including
  Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and cellular technologies.

  The invention reshaped how secure digital communication is engineered in an interconnected world.
recognition: |-
  


  * 1942: Patent granted, no deployment

  *  1960s–80s: Concept rediscovered in military research


  *  1997: Lamarr awarded the Electronic Frontier Foundation Pioneer Award


  *  Posthumous recognition as a foundational wireless innovator
associated_story: stories/veiled-genius-the-dual-legacy-of-hedy-lamarr-hollywood-icon-and-pioneer-of-secure-communications/

gallery:

  - https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcQmRlWEEb4kdChgLRVazqptgvrzuV8qKExiYg&s
tags:
  - frequency hopping
  - spread spectrum
  - wireless security
  - WWII technology
  - women in STEM
  - historical erasure
---
